declarations.comments: Test whether a value is not an element of a data structure.
declarations.title: notElem

declarations.comments:
Fold a data structure, accumulating values in some `Monoid`,
combining adjacent elements using the specified separator.
declarations.title: intercalate

declarations.comments: Fold a data structure, accumulating values in some `Monoid`.
declarations.title: fold

declarations.comments: Try to find an element in a data structure which satisfies a predicate mapping.
declarations.title: findMap

declarations.comments: Try to find an element in a data structure which satisfies a predicate.
declarations.title: find

declarations.comments: Test whether a value is an element of a data structure.
declarations.title: elem

declarations.comments:
`any f` is the same as `or <<< map f`; map a function over the structure,
and then get the disjunction of the results.
declarations.title: any

declarations.comments:
`all f` is the same as `and <<< map f`; map a function over the structure,
and then get the conjunction of the results.
declarations.title: all

declarations.comments:
Fold a data structure from the right, keeping all intermediate results
instead of only the final result. Note that the initial value does not
appear in the result (unlike Haskell's `Prelude.scanr`).

```purescript
scanr (+) 0  [1,2,3] = [1,3,6]
scanr (flip (-)) 10 [1,2,3] = [4,5,7]
```
declarations.title: scanr

declarations.comments:
Fold a data structure from the left, keeping all intermediate results
instead of only the final result. Note that the initial value does not
appear in the result (unlike Haskell's `Prelude.scanl`).

```purescript
scanl (+) 0  [1,2,3] = [1,3,6]
scanl (-) 10 [1,2,3] = [9,7,4]
```
declarations.title: scanl

modules.name: Data.Array
modules.comments:
Helper functions for working with immutable Javascript arrays.

_Note_: Depending on your use-case, you may prefer to use `Data.List` or
`Data.Sequence` instead, which might give better performance for certain
use cases. This module is useful when integrating with JavaScript libraries
which use arrays, but immutable arrays are not a practical data structure
for many use cases due to their poor asymptotics.

In addition to the functions in this module, Arrays have a number of
useful instances:

* `Functor`, which provides `map :: forall a b. (a -> b) -> Array a ->
  Array b`
* `Apply`, which provides `(<*>) :: forall a b. Array (a -> b) -> Array a
  -> Array b`. This function works a bit like a Cartesian product; the
  result array is constructed by applying each function in the first
  array to each value in the second, so that the result array ends up with
  a length equal to the product of the two arguments' lengths.
* `Bind`, which provides `(>>=) :: forall a b. (a -> Array b) -> Array a
  -> Array b` (this is the same as `concatMap`).
* `Semigroup`, which provides `(<>) :: forall a. Array a -> Array a ->
  Array a`, for concatenating arrays.
* `Foldable`, which provides a slew of functions for *folding* (also known
  as *reducing*) arrays down to one value. For example,
  `Data.Foldable.or` tests whether an array of `Boolean` values contains
  at least one `true` value.
* `Traversable`, which provides the PureScript version of a for-loop,
  allowing you to iterate over an array and accumulate effects.

declarations.comments: Convert an `Array` into an `Unfoldable` structure.
declarations.title: toUnfoldable

declarations.comments: Convert a `Foldable` structure into an `Array`.
declarations.title: fromFoldable

declarations.comments: Create an array of one element
declarations.title: singleton

declarations.comments: Create an array containing a range of integers, including both endpoints.
declarations.title: range

declarations.comments: Create an array containing a value repeated the specified number of times.
declarations.title: replicate

declarations.comments: An infix synonym for `range`.

Attempt a computation multiple times, requiring at least one success.

The `Lazy` constraint is used to generate the result lazily, to ensure
termination.
declarations.title: some

declarations.comments:
Attempt a computation multiple times, returning as many successful results
as possible (possibly zero).

The `Lazy` constraint is used to generate the result lazily, to ensure
termination.
declarations.title: many

declarations.comments: Test whether an array is empty.
declarations.title: null

declarations.comments: Get the number of elements in an array.
declarations.title: length

declarations.comments:
Attaches an element to the front of an array, creating a new array.

```purescript
cons 1 [2, 3, 4] = [1, 2, 3, 4]
```

Note, the running time of this function is `O(n)`.
declarations.title: cons

declarations.comments:
An infix alias for `cons`.

Note, the running time of this function is `O(n)`.
Append an element to the end of an array, creating a new array.
declarations.title: snoc

declarations.comments: Insert an element into a sorted array.
declarations.title: insert

declarations.comments:
Insert an element into a sorted array, using the specified function to
determine the ordering of elements.
declarations.title: insertBy

declarations.comments:
Get the first element in an array, or `Nothing` if the array is empty

Running time: `O(1)`.
declarations.title: head

declarations.comments:
Get the last element in an array, or `Nothing` if the array is empty

Running time: `O(1)`.
declarations.title: last

declarations.comments:
Get all but the first element of an array, creating a new array, or
`Nothing` if the array is empty

Running time: `O(n)` where `n` is the length of the array
declarations.title: tail

declarations.comments:
Get all but the last element of an array, creating a new array, or
`Nothing` if the array is empty.

Running time: `O(n)` where `n` is the length of the array
declarations.title: init

declarations.comments:
Break an array into its first element and remaining elements.

Using `uncons` provides a way of writing code that would use cons patterns
in Haskell or pre-PureScript 0.7:
``` purescript
f (x : xs) = something
f [] = somethingElse
```
Becomes:
``` purescript
f arr = case uncons arr of
  Just { head: x, tail: xs } -> something
  Nothing -> somethingElse
```
declarations.title: uncons

declarations.comments:
Break an array into its last element and all preceding elements.

Running time: `O(n)` where `n` is the length of the array
declarations.title: unsnoc

declarations.comments:
This function provides a safe way to read a value at a particular index
from an array.
declarations.title: index

declarations.comments: An infix version of `index`.
Find the index of the first element equal to the specified element.
declarations.title: elemIndex

declarations.comments: Find the index of the last element equal to the specified element.
declarations.title: elemLastIndex

declarations.comments: Find the first index for which a predicate holds.
declarations.title: findIndex

declarations.comments: Find the last index for which a predicate holds.
declarations.title: findLastIndex

declarations.comments:
Insert an element at the specified index, creating a new array, or
returning `Nothing` if the index is out of bounds.
declarations.title: insertAt

declarations.comments:
Delete the element at the specified index, creating a new array, or
returning `Nothing` if the index is out of bounds.
declarations.title: deleteAt

declarations.comments:
Change the element at the specified index, creating a new array, or
returning `Nothing` if the index is out of bounds.
declarations.title: updateAt

declarations.comments:
Apply a function to the element at the specified index, creating a new
array, or returning `Nothing` if the index is out of bounds.
declarations.title: modifyAt

declarations.comments:
Update or delete the element at the specified index by applying a
function to the current value, returning a new array or `Nothing` if the
index is out-of-bounds.
declarations.title: alterAt

declarations.comments: Reverse an array, creating a new array.
declarations.title: reverse

declarations.comments: Flatten an array of arrays, creating a new array.
declarations.title: concat

declarations.comments:
Apply a function to each element in an array, and flatten the results
into a single, new array.
declarations.title: concatMap

declarations.comments:
Filter an array, keeping the elements which satisfy a predicate function,
creating a new array.
declarations.title: filter

declarations.comments:
Partition an array using a predicate function, creating a set of
new arrays. One for the values satisfying the predicate function
and one for values that don't.
declarations.title: partition

declarations.comments:
Filter where the predicate returns a `Boolean` in some `Applicative`.

```purescript
powerSet :: forall a. Array a -> Array (Array a)
powerSet = filterA (const [true, false])
```
declarations.title: filterA

declarations.comments:
Apply a function to each element in an array, keeping only the results
which contain a value, creating a new array.
declarations.title: mapMaybe

declarations.comments:
Filter an array of optional values, keeping only the elements which contain
a value, creating a new array.
declarations.title: catMaybes

declarations.comments:
Apply a function to each element in an array, supplying a generated
zero-based index integer along with the element, creating an array
with the new elements.
declarations.title: mapWithIndex

declarations.comments:
Change the elements at the specified indices in index/value pairs.
Out-of-bounds indices will have no effect.
declarations.title: updateAtIndices

declarations.comments:
Apply a function to the element at the specified indices,
creating a new array. Out-of-bounds indices will have no effect.
declarations.title: modifyAtIndices

declarations.comments: Sort the elements of an array in increasing order, creating a new array.
declarations.title: sort

declarations.comments:
Sort the elements of an array in increasing order, where elements are
compared using the specified partial ordering, creating a new array.
declarations.title: sortBy

declarations.comments:
Sort the elements of an array in increasing order, where elements are
sorted based on a projection
declarations.title: sortWith

declarations.comments: Extract a subarray by a start and end index.
declarations.title: slice

declarations.comments:
Keep only a number of elements from the start of an array, creating a new
array.
declarations.title: take

declarations.comments:
Calculate the longest initial subarray for which all element satisfy the
specified predicate, creating a new array.
declarations.title: takeWhile

declarations.comments: Drop a number of elements from the start of an array, creating a new array.
declarations.title: drop

declarations.comments:
Remove the longest initial subarray for which all element satisfy the
specified predicate, creating a new array.
declarations.title: dropWhile

declarations.comments:
Split an array into two parts:

1. the longest initial subarray for which all elements satisfy the
   specified predicate
2. the remaining elements

```purescript
span (\n -> n % 2 == 1) [1,3,2,4,5] == { init: [1,3], rest: [2,4,5] }
```

Running time: `O(n)`.
declarations.title: span

declarations.comments:
Group equal, consecutive elements of an array into arrays.

```purescript
group [1,1,2,2,1] == [[1,1],[2,2],[1]]
```
declarations.title: group

declarations.comments:
Sort and then group the elements of an array into arrays.

```purescript
group' [1,1,2,2,1] == [[1,1,1],[2,2]]
```
declarations.title: group'

declarations.comments:
Group equal, consecutive elements of an array into arrays, using the
specified equivalence relation to detemine equality.
declarations.title: groupBy

declarations.comments: Remove the duplicates from an array, creating a new array.
declarations.title: nub

declarations.comments:
Remove the duplicates from an array, where element equality is determined
by the specified equivalence relation, creating a new array.
declarations.title: nubBy

declarations.comments:
Calculate the union of two arrays. Note that duplicates in the first array
are preserved while duplicates in the second array are removed.

Running time: `O(n^2)`
declarations.title: union

declarations.comments:
Calculate the union of two arrays, using the specified function to
determine equality of elements. Note that duplicates in the first array
are preserved while duplicates in the second array are removed.
declarations.title: unionBy

declarations.comments:
Delete the first element of an array which is equal to the specified value,
creating a new array.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: delete

declarations.comments:
Delete the first element of an array which matches the specified value,
under the equivalence relation provided in the first argument, creating a
new array.
declarations.title: deleteBy

declarations.comments:
Delete the first occurrence of each element in the second array from the
first array, creating a new array.

Running time: `O(n*m)`, where n is the length of the first array, and m is
the length of the second.
declarations.title: difference

declarations.comments:
Calculate the intersection of two arrays, creating a new array. Note that
duplicates in the first array are preserved while duplicates in the second
array are removed.
declarations.title: intersect

declarations.comments:
Calculate the intersection of two arrays, using the specified equivalence
relation to compare elements, creating a new array. Note that duplicates
in the first array are preserved while duplicates in the second array are
removed.
declarations.title: intersectBy

declarations.comments:
Apply a function to pairs of elements at the same index in two arrays,
collecting the results in a new array.

If one array is longer, elements will be discarded from the longer array.

For example

```purescript
zipWith (*) [1, 2, 3] [4, 5, 6, 7] == [4, 10, 18]
```
declarations.title: zipWith

declarations.comments:
A generalization of `zipWith` which accumulates results in some
`Applicative` functor.
declarations.title: zipWithA

declarations.comments:
Takes two arrays and returns an array of corresponding pairs.
If one input array is short, excess elements of the longer array are
discarded.
declarations.title: zip

declarations.comments:
Transforms an array of pairs into an array of first components and an
array of second components.
declarations.title: unzip

declarations.comments: Perform a fold using a monadic step function.
declarations.title: foldM

declarations.comments: Find the element of an array at the specified index.
declarations.title: unsafeIndex

modules.name: Data.Array.Partial
modules.comments: Partial helper functions for working with immutable arrays.

declarations.comments:
Get the first element of a non-empty array.

Running time: `O(1)`.
declarations.title: head

declarations.comments:
Get all but the first element of a non-empty array.

Running time: `O(n)`, where `n` is the length of the array.
declarations.title: tail

declarations.comments:
Get the last element of a non-empty array.

Running time: `O(1)`.
declarations.title: last

declarations.comments:
Get all but the last element of a non-empty array.

Running time: `O(n)`, where `n` is the length of the array.
declarations.title: init

modules.name: Data.Array.ST
modules.comments:
Helper functions for working with mutable arrays using the `ST` effect.

This module can be used when performance is important and mutation is a local effect.

declarations.comments:
A reference to a mutable array.

The first type parameter represents the memory region which the array belongs to.
The second type parameter defines the type of elements of the mutable array.

The runtime representation of a value of type `STArray h a` is the same as that of `Array a`,
except that mutation is allowed.
declarations.title: STArray

declarations.comments: An element and its index.
declarations.title: Assoc

declarations.comments:
**DEPRECATED**: Use `unsafeFreeze` together with `runST` instead.

Freeze a mutable array, creating an immutable array. Use this function as you would use
`runST` to freeze a mutable reference.

The rank-2 type prevents the reference from escaping the scope of `runSTArray`.
declarations.title: runSTArray

declarations.comments:
Perform an effect requiring a mutable array on a copy of an immutable array,
safely returning the result as an immutable array.
declarations.title: withArray

declarations.comments:
O(1). Convert a mutable array to an immutable array, without copying. The mutable
array must not be mutated afterwards.
declarations.title: unsafeFreeze

declarations.comments: Create an empty mutable array.
declarations.title: emptySTArray

declarations.comments: Create a mutable copy of an immutable array.
declarations.title: thaw

declarations.comments: Create an immutable copy of a mutable array.
declarations.title: freeze

declarations.comments: Read the value at the specified index in a mutable array.
declarations.title: peekSTArray

declarations.comments: Change the value at the specified index in a mutable array.
declarations.title: pokeSTArray

declarations.comments:
Append an element to the end of a mutable array. Returns the new length of
the array.
declarations.title: pushSTArray

declarations.comments:
Append the values in an immutable array to the end of a mutable array.
Returns the new length of the mutable array.
declarations.title: pushAllSTArray

declarations.comments: Mutate the element at the specified index using the supplied function.
declarations.title: modifySTArray

declarations.comments: Remove and/or insert elements from/into a mutable array at the specified index.
declarations.title: spliceSTArray

declarations.comments:
Create an immutable copy of a mutable array, where each element
is labelled with its index in the original array.
declarations.title: toAssocArray

declarations.comments:
This type provides a slightly easier way of iterating over an array's
elements in an STArray computation, without having to keep track of
indices.
declarations.title: Iterator

declarations.comments:
Make an Iterator given an indexing function into an array (or anything
else). If `xs :: Array a`, the standard way to create an iterator over
`xs` is to use `iterator (xs !! _)`, where `(!!)` comes from `Data.Array`.
declarations.title: iterator

declarations.comments:
Perform an action once for each item left in an iterator. If the action
itself also advances the same iterator, `iterate` will miss those items
out.
declarations.title: iterate

declarations.comments:
Get the next item out of an iterator, advancing it. Returns Nothing if the
Iterator is exhausted.
declarations.title: next

declarations.comments: Get the next item out of an iterator without advancing it.
declarations.title: peek

declarations.comments: Check whether an iterator has been exhausted.
declarations.title: exhausted

declarations.comments:
Extract elements from an iterator and push them on to an STArray for as
long as those elements satisfy a given predicate.
declarations.title: pushWhile

declarations.comments: Push the entire remaining contents of an iterator onto an STArray.
declarations.title: pushAll

modules.name: Data.Array.ST.Partial
modules.comments:
Partial functions for working with mutable arrays using the `ST` effect.

This module is particularly helpful when performance is very important.

declarations.comments: Read the value at the specified index in a mutable array.
declarations.title: peekSTArray

declarations.comments: Change the value at the specified index in a mutable array.
declarations.title: pokeSTArray
